case_name: Maneklal Ujamshi v. Income Tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2454 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2454 of 1966.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated February 19/22, 1965 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 2 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated February 19/22, 1965 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 2 of 1962.

facts.text: The judgment of the Bombay High Court was dated the 22nd February, 1965 in Income-tax Reference No. 2 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought by certificate from the, judgment of the Bombay High Court dated the 22nd February, 1965 in Income-tax Reference No. 2 of 1962.

facts.text: In the year 1951 the assessee Maneklal Ujamshi made a gift of 1,184 ordinary and 155 preference shares in Changdeo Sugar Mills Ltd. to his wife Bai Laxmibai.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1951 the assessee Maneklal Ujamshi  hereinafter referred to as the assessee  made a gift of 1,184 ordinary and 155 preference shares in Changdeo Sugar Mills Ltd. to his wife Bai Laxmibai.

facts.text: The total value of the transferred shares on the date of the transfer was Rs. 68,730/-

anchor.surface_text: The total value of these transferred shares on the date of the transfer was Rs. 68,730/- Subsequent to the transfer the companypany companyverted the preference shares into ordinary shares giving the shareholders 8 ordinary shares for each preference share with the result that on December 31, 1954, Bai Laxmibai held in all 2,424 ordinary shares of the mills.

facts.text: The company converted the preference shares into ordinary shares giving 8 ordinary shares for each preference share.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the transfer the companypany companyverted the preference shares into ordinary shares giving the shareholders 8 ordinary shares for each preference share with the result that on December 31, 1954, Bai Laxmibai held in all 2,424 ordinary shares of the mills.

facts.text: On December 31, 1954, Bai Laxmibai held 2,424 ordinary shares of the mills.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that on December 31, 1954, Bai Laxmibai held in all 2,424 ordinary shares of the mills. Out, of these 2,424 shares. Bai Laxmibai sold 2,400 shares on August 1. 1956, for the sum of Rs. 1,54,800/- resulting in a capital gain of Rs. 70,860/- as companyputed under s. 12B of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Bai Laxmibai sold 2,400 shares on August 1, 1956, for Rs. 1,54,800/- resulting in a capital gain of Rs. 70,860/- computed under s. 12B of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Out, of these 2,424 shares. Bai Laxmibai sold 2,400 shares on August 1. 1956, for the sum of Rs. 1,54,800/- resulting in a capital gain of Rs. 70,860/- as companyputed under s. 12B of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The whole amount realised by the sale of the shares was deposited by Bai Laxmibai with M/s. A.H. Bhivandiwalla Co., in which Maneklal and his son Sevantilal were partners.

anchor.surface_text: The whole amount realised by the sale of the shares was deposited by Bai Laxmibai with M s. A.H. BhivandiwaIla Co., in which Maneklal as well as his son, Sevantilal, happened to be partners.

facts.text: The amount deposited by Bai Laxmibai fetched a yearly interest of Rs. 9,288/-

anchor.surface_text: The amount deposited by Bai Laxmibai fetched a yearly interest of Rs. 9,288/-. In the assessment of Maneklal for the assessment year 1957-58 the Income Tax Officer included the amount of Rs. 70,860/- which was the profit made by Bai Laxmibai on the sale of the shares, as income of Maneklal under s. 16 3  a  iii  of the Indian Income Tax Act.

facts.text: In the assessment of Maneklal for AY 1957-58, ITO included Rs. 70,860/- (capital gain by wife) as income under s.16(3)(a)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment of Maneklal for the assessment year 1957-58 the Income Tax Officer included the amount of Rs. 70,860/- which was the profit made by Bai Laxmibai on the sale of the shares, as income of Maneklal under s. 16 3  a  iii  of the Indian Income Tax Act.

facts.text: In assessments of Maneklal for AY 1958-59 and 1959-60, ITO included Rs. 9,288/- (interest earned by wife) as income under s.16(3)(a)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in the assessment of Maneklal for the assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60, the Income Tax Officer included in each year the amount of Rs. 9,288 which was the interest earned by Bai Laxmibai on the deposit of the sale proceeds with M s. Bhivandiwalla and Co. as the income of Maneklal under s. 16 3  a  iii .

facts.text: Appeals were filed against the three assessment orders before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals against all these three assessment orders were filed before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: AAC dismissed the appeal for AY 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal against the first assessment order for the assessment year 1957-58 the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the view taken by the Income Tax Officer and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: For AY 1958-59 and 1959-60, AAC partly allowed appeals, including only Rs. 4,138/- or Rs. 4,183/- (interest on gifted value Rs. 69,730/-) under s.16(3)(a)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: In the other two appeals, he partly allowed the appeals taking the view that only that part of the interest which was attributable to the monetary value of the shares companyered by the shares at the time of the gift was liable to be included in the total income of Maneklal in accordance with the provisions o.f s. 16 3  a  iii  and the balance companyld number be included under the said provision. Since the monetary value of the shares gifted to Bai Laxmibai at the time when the gift was made was only Rs. 69,730/-, the interest attributable to it worked out at Rs. 4,l 38/-.

facts.text: Assessee appealed AAC orders to Appellate Tribunal; Department appealed partial relief for 1958-59 and 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: Against the orders of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on these appeals the assessee appealed to the Appellate Tribunal. The Department, on the other hand, appealed against the orders of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner for the years 1958-59 and 1959-60 insofar as they allowed exemption in respect of Rs. 4,183/- out of the total amount of Rs. 9,288/- for each year.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal dismissed assessee's appeal for AY 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal dismissed the appeal of the assessee with regard to the assessment year 1957-58.

facts.text: For AY 1958-59 and 1959-60, Tribunal allowed Department's appeals and dismissed assessee's appeal for 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1958-59 and/959-60, the Appellate Tribunal allowed the appeals of the Department and dismissed the appeal of the assessee for the assessment. year 1959-60.

facts.text: Tribunal upheld inclusion of Rs. 70,860/- for AY 1957-58 and Rs. 9,288/- for each of 1958-59 and 1959-60 in Maneklal's income.

anchor.surface_text: According to these decisions of the Appellate Tribunal the result was that for the assessment year 1957-58 the order of the Income Tax Officer that the amount of Rs, 70,860/- which was the profit or gain on the sale of the shares by Bai Laxmibai was liable to be included in the total income of Maneklal was upheld and for the later two, years the entire amount of interest viz., Rs. 9,288/- was held to be liable to be included in the total income of Maneklal in each of those two years.

facts.text: At instance of assessee, Tribunal stated case to High Court on four questions of law.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, at the instance of the assessee, the Appellate Tribunal stated a case to the High Court on the following questions of law

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated February 19, 1965 answered first question in affirmative against assessee, questions 2 and 4 in favour of assessee, question 3 in affirmative in favour of Department.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated February 19, 1965 the High Court answered the first question in the affirmative and against the assessee. It answered questions Nos. 2 4 in favour of the assessee and against the Department. As regards question No. 3, the High Court answered it in the affirmative and in favour of the Department.

facts.text: Counsel for assessee did not press question No. 3.

anchor.surface_text: The reason was that Counsel for the assessee did number press it or challenge the companyrectness of the view taken by the Appellate Tribunal and accepted as companyrect the companyclusion of the Tribunal with regard to the point involved in that question.

Section 16 3  a  iii  of the Income Tax Act, 1922 provides as follows in computing the total income of any individual for the purpose of assessment, there shall be included -  a  so much of the income of a wife of such individual as arises directly or indirectly from assets transferred directly or indirectly to the wife by the husband otherwise than for adequate companysideration or in connection with an agreement to live apart.

concepts.interpretation: Income of wife arising directly or indirectly from assets transferred by husband without adequate consideration includes capital gains from sale of such assets, as 'income' takes amended meaning including capital gains.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12B of the Income Tax Act enacts The tax shah be payable by an assesee under the head capital gains in respect of any profits or gains arising from the sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer of a capital asset effected after the 31st day of March, 1956, and such profits and gains shall be deemed to be income of the previous year in which the sale. exchange, relinquishment or transfer took place

arguments.claim: The capital gain of Rs. 70,860/- from sale of gifted shares by wife arises directly or indirectly from assets transferred by husband without adequate consideration and is includible in husband's income under s.16(3)(a)(iii)

anchor.surface_text: According to the Income Tax Officer the gain which had resulted from the sale of the shares was the income of the wife of the assessee which arose directly or indirectly from the assets transferred by the assessee to his wife otherwise than for adequate companysideration and therefore was required to be included in the companyputation of the total income of Maneklal.

arguments.claim: Income under s.16(3)(a)(iii) means income produced by the asset while held by wife, not capital gains from its sale

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the first question Mr. Mehta put forward the argument that what companyes within the ambit of s. 16 3  a  iii  is the income from the transferred assets, which is different from the profit or gain arising from the sale of the transferred assets, or in other words, the capital gains from the transferred assets. It was argued in the first place that what companyes within the ambit of s. 16  3   a   iii  was the income from the assets i.e., the income which the asset produces while it companytinues to remain in the hands of the assessee and does number include the gain which the assessee makes by selling the asset and parting with possession of it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: any capital gain chargeable under section 12B Section 12B of the Income Tax Act enacts The tax shah be payable by an assesee under the head capital g

arguments.court_reasoning: No logical distinction; both investment income and sale gain arise or spring from the asset

arguments.claim: s.16(3)(a)(iii) enacted in 1937 when 'income' excluded capital gains (included only from 1947), so capital gains not covered

anchor.surface_text: It was argued in the second place that s. 16 3  a  iii  was enacted in 1937 when the word income did number include capital gains and income from property was understood to be income falling under that head in s. 6 of the Act. The inclusion of capital gains in the definition of income was for the first time enacted in 1947.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he assessee and does number include the gain which the assessee makes by selling the asset and parting with possession of it. We see numberjustificati

arguments.court_reasoning: Amended s.2(6C) definition applies; nothing in context or language excludes capital gains

arguments.claim: No logical distinction between income from investment in asset and gain from sale of asset; both arise from the asset

anchor.surface_text: We see numberjustification for this argument. In our opinion there is numberlogical distinction between income arising from the asset transferred to the wife and income arising from the sale of the assets so transferred. The profits or gains which arise from the sale of the asset would arise or spring from the asset, although the operation by which the profits or gains is made to arise out of the asset is the operation of the sale.

arguments.claim: 'Income' in s.16(3)(a)(iii) construed per amended s.2(6C) definition including capital gains; no contextual exclusion

anchor.surface_text: It is true that at the time when s. 16 3  a  iii  was enacted, the definition of income did number include capital gains but capital gains having been brought within the meaning of income in s. 2 6C  the expression income as used in s. 16 3   a  must be companystrued according to the amended definition of the word and would, therefore, include capital gains. There is numberhing in the companytext or language of s. 16 3   a  of the Act to suggest that capital gains are excluded from its scope.

arguments.claim: s.16(3)(a)(iii) to be construed purposively to prevent tax avoidance by asset transfer to wife

anchor.surface_text: We see numberreason why a restricted interpretation should be given to the provisions of s. 16 3  a  iii  as companytended for the appellant. On the companytrary, the object of the enactment of the section is to prevent avoidance of tax or reducing the incidence of tax on the part of the assessee by transfer of his assets to. his wife or minor child. It is a sound rule of interpretation that a statute should be so companystrued as to prevent the mischief and to advance the remedy according to the true intention of the makers of the statute.

holdings.text: There is no logical distinction between income arising from the asset transferred to the wife and income arising from the sale of the assets so transferred. The profits or gains which arise from the sale of the asset would arise or spring from the asset.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberjustification for this argument. In our opinion there is numberlogical distinction between income arising from the asset transferred to the wife and income arising from the sale of the assets so transferred. The profits or gains which arise from the sale of the asset would arise or spring from the asset, although the operation by which the profits or gains is made to arise out of the asset is the operation of the sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both investment yield and sale gain spring from the transferred asset despite differing processes of realization.

holdings.text: The expression 'income' as used in s.16(3)(a) must be construed according to the amended definition in s.2(6C) and would therefore include capital gains. There is nothing in the context or language of s.16(3)(a) to suggest that capital gains are excluded from its scope.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that at the time when s. 16 3 a iii was enacted, the definition of income did number include capital gains but capital gains having been brought within the meaning of income in s. 2 6C the expression income as used in s. 16 3 a must be companystrued according to the amended definition of the word and would, therefore, include capital gains. There is numberhing in the companytext or language of s. 16 3 a of the Act to suggest that capital gains are excluded from its scope.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended definition of 'income' applies prospectively to interpretation of earlier provisions absent contrary context.

holdings.text: No restricted interpretation to s.16(3)(a)(iii); object is to prevent tax avoidance by asset transfers to wife; construe to suppress mischief and advance remedy.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberreason why a restricted interpretation should be given to the provisions of s. 16 3 a iii as companytended for the appellant. On the companytrary, the object of the enactment of the section is to prevent avoidance of tax or reducing the incidence of tax on the part of the assessee by transfer of his assets to. his wife or minor child. It is a sound rule of interpretation that a statute should be so companystrued as to prevent the mischief and to advance the remedy according to the true intention of the makers of the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction aligns with anti-avoidance intent of provision.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable to accept Mr. Mehtas argument on this aspect of the case.

outcome.relief_summary: Court rejects appellant's contention that capital gains from sale of gifted shares are not includible under s.16(3)(a)(iii); holds that 'income' includes capital gains and arises from transferred assets.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberjustification for this argument. In our opinion there is numberlogical distinction between income arising from the asset transferred to the wife and income arising from the sale of the assets so transferred. The profits or gains which arise from the sale of the asset would arise or spring from the asset, although the operation by which the profits or gains is made to arise out of the asset is the operation of the sale.
We are, therefore, unable to accept Mr. Mehtas argument on this aspect of the case.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that at the time when s. 16 3 a iii was enacted, the definition of income did number include capital gains but capital gains having been brought within the meaning of income in s. 2 6C the expression income as used in s. 16 3 a must be companystrued according to the amended definition of the word and would, therefore, include capital gains. There is numberhing in the companytext or language of s. 16 3 a of the Act to suggest that capital gains are excluded from its scope.
We are, therefore, unable to accept Mr. Mehtas argument on this aspect of the case.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberreason why a restricted interpretation should be given to the provisions of s. 16 3 a iii as companytended for the appellant. On the companytrary, the object of the enactment of the section is to prevent avoidance of tax or reducing the incidence of tax on the part of the assessee by transfer of his assets to. his wife or minor child. It is a sound rule of interpretation that a statute should be so companystrued as to prevent the mischief and to advance the remedy according to the true intention of the makers of the statute.
We are, therefore, unable to accept Mr. Mehtas argument on this aspect of the case.
